Some quick tips while am at it: -Use parallel quarter-chords (probably called something else, basically 2 fourths stacked EAD e.g.) and play any preferred major pentatonic over it.
-Play blues scale and then venture out to play the chord-tones of the augmented fourth in the key you are in (A+ in E-blues)
-Play major pentatonic on major seven chords, one note above the root, this will give you the 13 colour naturally in the licks (D-pentatonic during Cmaj7)
-While soloing on sustained chords that hold for quite a while, switch scales, modes and keys on top of it (play for example E-blues, A-blues, D-Major scale, whole tone scale, diminished scale, E Phrygian back to E-blues over a sustained E- Chord (E minor))
-Play all the "wrong" notes.
-Purchase Vincent Persichettis "Twentieth Century Harmony"

My dear blue friend, I shall do my duty as an jazz-fusion addict and introduce you to the gospel-holyness of Cory Henry. Start playing non-functional an poly-tonal and soon your licks will be as sick as a hitler with cancer. Just YouTube Cory Henry and Cory Henry Analysis. My introduction to this god was trough the band Snarky Puppy and their song Lingus. Now little sparrow, fly out in the world of fusion and surf the waves back to prosperity.

I'm no engineer, but I'm a composer! And I'm Swedish! Hit me up if you need any music! Do mostly epic orchestral stuff but also some experimental electronic as well as some chiptune etc. Here are some links to my work
[Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/4Q5ACP3WvOdVQgzWZYkyL7) [Apple Music](https://itunes.apple.com/se/artist/arvid-olson/id666457106) [SoundCloud](https://soundcloud.com/arvid-olson) [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCpmCKkqotPb6mS8HM-PXLrw? ab_channel=ArvidOlson) [My Band's YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCvgqi4vlDw3mAf2P8UW5V9w? ab_channel=FluviusBand)
BTW: I'm currently writing a piano concerto that will be finished sometime in may, so until then, I'm quite busy :)
Oh, and "You'd love to get my music in your game (and here is why:)" is usually also a better mindset when talking with serious people :)

A tip: Usually, in this business, regarding composers and artists, one can not "love to get their foot 'in the door'" but rather really bang on many doors and kick their foot in! But great that you are trying anyway!

In roman numeral analysis you use the scale steps as a basis. In "funktionsanys" which the best translation for, but does not exactly mean "diatonic functional analysis" you don't care about the steps at all but only the harmonic function of the chord.
For example, C Am Dm7 G7 would be written T Tp Sp7 D7 (TONIC TONICparallel SUBDOMINANTparallel7 DOMINANT7)
If we had C Am F# G7 that would be T Tp D~~D~~7b9 D7
D~~D~~7b9 is a D7b9(chord) without the D
EDIT: clarifying stuff
Yes thank you very much!

And I'm just wondering how you analyse everything in major? Don't you want to point out the dominant~ness of for example A7 when it's leading to Dm in a song played in D dorian, or am I missing something?
EDIT: Well I guess that was a bad example because of A7 not being native to D dorian, but let's change it to D harmonic minor and use the same example!

Love this ^ because i don't know what the "common practise period" is, and that means I can learn something new! I'm however Swedish and not used to English terminology. :) When I go to the Swedish and English Wikipedia pages for the "kyrkotonarter" and "gregorian mode" they actually talk about a bit different stuff, so I fear that we may misunderstand each other.
However I at least thought that the scale we where actually talking about was the DEFGABCD. And if I was going to make a roman numeral analysis (which I wouldn't because I much prefer Diatonic Functional Analysis (just called "Functional Analysis in Swedish)) I would talk about every triad containing only scale steps like I was talking about for example a natural A minor scale. This means that the vi chord would be BDF and not BbDF like if it was a natural D minor scale. I fear however I may be missing your point and if you would be so kind and have the time, please try and explain for me! :)
Merry Christmas!

Wtf are you talking about, the modes aka gregorian modes was mostly used in the middle ages and idk where you studied music theory, but it's definitely a "basic part of traditional music theory" and one should definitely analyse dorian as dorian and not something else (well should and should, but I don't see why not).
